questions.question: A healthy 65-year-old male was found on routine examination to have a symptomless central abdominal pulsatile mass. The initial management should be:
options: Doppler examination of the arterial system
questions.explanation: Abdominal ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice. It is non-invasive, accurate for diagnosis, and effective for measuring the size of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About aspiration of cold abscess, all of the following is true except:
questions.explanation: A cold abscess should always be aspirated through non-dependent healthy skin (Z-technique) to prevent chronic leakage and sinus formation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About Hodgkin's disease, the term 'drift back' expression means:
options: Lower dose of treatment is needed after some time
With time there is affection of the LNs draining the back
With time the lesion becomes less differentiated
questions.explanation: 'Drift back' refers to the phenomenon where tumor cells lose differentiation over time or upon recurrence, becoming more aggressive.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About Hodgkin's disease, all the following are true except:
options: No malignant cells in the Blood stream
questions.explanation: Hodgkin's disease characteristically has a bimodal age distribution (peaks in young adulthood 15-35 years and older adults >55 years), not unimodal.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About incision of the cold abscess, all of the following is true except:
questions.explanation: Incision is generally contraindicated for cold abscesses unless secondarily infected. Drains are avoided because they lead to chronic tuberculous sinuses.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About lymphadenoid type of TB lymphadenitis, all the following are true except:
questions.explanation: Lymphadenoid TB is a hyperplastic form affecting the whole node structure diffusely. The statement 'No affection of medulla' is incorrect.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following cause generalized lymphadenopathy except:
questions.explanation: TB lymphadenitis typically causes localized or regional lymphadenopathy (commonly cervical), unlike leukemia, lymphoma, and viral infections which cause generalized disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An asymptomatic infrarenal abdominal aneurysm measuring 8 cm in diameter was discovered in a 70-year-old male who was otherwise healthy. The proper management is by:
questions.explanation: An AAA >5.5 cm in diameter or one that is expanding rapidly is an indication for elective repair to prevent rupture. 8 cm poses a significant risk of rupture.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Filarial edema is:
questions.explanation: Filarial lymphedema begins as pitting edema. Over time, chronic inflammation and fibrosis occur, causing the edema to become non-pitting (elephantiasis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: History suggesting lymphedema include:
questions.explanation: Lymphedema risk factors include residence in filarial endemic zones, prior lymph node dissection (mastectomy), and history of recurrent skin infections (erysipelas) which damage lymphatics further.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hodgkin's disease is associated with:
questions.explanation: Genetic mutations, including abnormalities in the P53 tumor suppressor gene, have been implicated in the pathogenesis of various lymphomas, including Hodgkin's disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A young man with a posterior knee dislocation has intact pulses after reduction but develops leg pain and foot numbness 6 hours later. What is the proper initial management?
options: Observation for frank signs of ischaemia
X-ray examination of the lumbosacral spine
questions.explanation: Posterior knee dislocation risks popliteal artery injury. Delayed ischemia requires immediate arteriography to define the lesion before revascularization. Waiting is dangerous.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In lymphatic born type of TB lymphadenitis, LN examination will show all the following except:
questions.explanation: TB lymph nodes are typically matted and firm or soft (caseating). 'Rubbery' consistency is the hallmark of Lymphoma (Hodgkin's), not TB.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Indicate the incorrect statement about filarial elephantiasis:
options: Usually affects the lower limbs and scrotum
Is rarely associated with other filarial lesions
May be complicated by lymphorrhoea, eczema and ulceration
Is characterized by recurrent attacks of elephantoid fever
questions.explanation: Elephantiasis (chronic stage 3 lymphedema) consists of irreversible fibrosis. It does not respond readily to medical antifilarial treatment, which targets the parasite.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Indication of surgical treatment of lymphedema:
questions.explanation: Surgery for lymphedema is reserved for cases causing significant disability, recurrent infections, or immense size, after failure of conservative therapy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Lymphatic born TB lymphadenitis is more common in:
questions.explanation: TB lymphadenitis is historically and statistically more common in children and young adults.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Mycobacterium TB is cultured upon:
questions.explanation: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is cultured on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium, which is an egg-based medium containing malachite green to inhibit the growth of contaminants.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Non-Hodgkin lymphomas differ from Hodgkin's disease in all of the following except:
options: Commonly occur in the very young and very old
Are not associated with fever or pruritis
Do not primarily involve the gastrointestinal tract
The affected lymph nodes fuse with each other and infiltrate the surrounding structures
Carry a poorer prognosis than Hodgkin's disease
questions.explanation: NHL frequently involves extranodal sites like the GI tract. The statement claiming it does NOT involves GI tract is false, making it the correct exception.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Reconstructive arterial surgery is recommended for patients with the following manifestations of ischemia except:
questions.explanation: Surgery is usually reserved for Critical Limb Ischemia (rest pain, ulcers, gangrene). Intermittent claudication is typically managed conservatively unless incapacitating.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Staging of Hodgkin's disease should include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Historically, 'Staging Laparotomy' (including splenectomy, liver biopsy, and node sampling) was the standard for Hodgkin's staging, though now largely replaced by PET/CT.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Swiss roll cake operation is a surgical treatment of:
questions.explanation: The 'Swiss Roll' operation is a historical excisional procedure for treating lymphedema, where subcutaneous tissue is excised and skin flaps are rolled/sutured.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest 1ry complex of TB is:
options: Tonsils + Lymph vessel + upper deep cervical LNs
questions.explanation: While pulmonary is most common globally, in the context of surgical TB questions (scrofula) or bovine TB areas, the Tonsillar/Cervical complex is often cited as the classic route.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest site of Burkitt's lymphoma:
questions.explanation: Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly the African endemic variety, most classically presents as a rapidly growing tumor of the jaw or facial bones in children.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about Burkitt's lymphoma are correct except:
options: Is most common in Central Africa
Presents clinically by a rapidly growing tumor of the jaw or orbit
Has the same histological picture as lymphosarcoma
Is due to combined viral and malarial etiology
questions.explanation: Burkitt's lymphoma has a unique histological appearance known as 'starry sky' pattern (macrophages amidst tumor cells), which distinguishes it from other lymphosarcomas.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The malignant cells are present in the blood stream in:
questions.explanation: Leukemia is defined by malignant cells in the blood/marrow. Lymphomas are tissue-based tumors, though they can leukemize late in the course.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common cause of lymphedema:
questions.explanation: Globally, the most common cause of lymphedema is lymphatic filariasis (infection with Wuchereria bancrofti). In developed countries, it is often secondary to cancer treatment.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site of Hodgkin's lymphoma is:
questions.explanation: Hodgkin's lymphoma typically arises in supradiaphragmatic lymph nodes, with the cervical region being the most common site of presentation (60-80% of cases).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The vector of Filaria Bancrofti is:
questions.explanation: The mosquito vector responsible for transmitting Wuchereria bancrofti (Filaria) is Culex pipiens (specifically Culex fatigans), whereas Anopheles transmits malaria.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The worst prognosis of Hodgkin's disease is with:
questions.explanation: Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma is the least common subtype and carries the poorest prognosis, often presenting with advanced disease in older patients.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements about primary lymphedema is correct:
options: Is due to congenital hypoplasia of lymphatics
May respond to conservative treatment in the early stages
questions.explanation: The question asks for the FALSE statement (based on key B). Primary lymphedema does NOT always manifest at birth; most cases appear during puberty (Praecox) or later.
questions.subject: General Surgery
